description:
Anopheles coluzzii is a species of mosquito that belongs to the Anopheles gambiae complex, which is a group of closely related mosquito species that are important vectors of malaria in sub-Saharan Africa. Anopheles coluzzii is a member of the M molecular form of the Anopheles gambiae complex, which was previously known as Anopheles gambiae s.s. (sensu stricto).

Anopheles coluzzii is primarily found in West and Central Africa, and it is known to be a highly efficient vector of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum, which is the most deadly species of Plasmodium that infects humans. The species is well-adapted to human-modified environments, such as urban and agricultural areas, and it is often associated with the use of insecticide-treated bed nets and other malaria control interventions.

Anopheles coluzzii is morphologically similar to other members of the Anopheles gambiae complex, but it can be distinguished by genetic and behavioral characteristics. For example, Anopheles coluzzii is known to have a more anthropophilic (human-feeding) behavior compared to some other Anopheles species, which can influence its role in malaria transmission.

Understanding the biology and ecology of Anopheles coluzzii is important for the development of effective malaria control strategies in the regions where it is prevalent, as it can help to target interventions more precisely and reduce the burden of this deadly disease.
